content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provide for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" cite the agreement of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes to reduced water supply facilities for a final settlement of their claims. The Act defines terms such as Agreement, Animas-La Plata Project, Dolores Project, and Tribe/Tribes. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE COLORADO UTE INDIAN WATER RIGHTS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1988. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 amended Section 6(a) to provide for the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acre-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This includes a pumping plant and reservoir inlet conduit for municipal and industrial water allocations to the Southern Ute Tribe not to exceed 16,525 acre-feet annually. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocated water to various entities, including the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District, with specific annual depletion limits for each. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocated water to entities like the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District, with specific annual depletion limits. Tribal construction costs for the Animas-La Plata Project are nonreimbursable, while nontribal water capital obligations will be repaid by designated entities. The San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado have cost-sharing obligations for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement. Certain costs for the Animas-La Plata Project are nonreimbursable, including those for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources, and fish and wildlife mitigation. Tribal water allocations from the project are also specified. The San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado have cost-sharing obligations for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement. Certain costs for the Animas-La Plata Project are nonreimbursable, including those for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources, and fish and wildlife mitigation. Tribal water allocations from the project are also specified, with the Secretary paying for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs until the water is used by the Tribe. Repayment of pro rata share is required as the water allocation is utilized. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to require repayment of pro rata share of construction costs and annual operation costs by the Tribe when using water allocations. The Secretary will provide necessary actions for water supplies at the request of specific water conservancy districts. The Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary will take necessary actions to ensure water supplies after the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. If additional water depletions are consistent with the Endangered Species Act, allocations will be made accordingly. The Secretary will allocate water among beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in accordance with an agreement. The Secretary shall transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries to fulfill project purposes. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in accordance with State law, to fulfill project purposes. Reports from the Department of the Interior and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service are considered adequate to meet requirements under environmental laws. The Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act do not apply to certain amendments and construction activities related to the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. This exemption does not impact other construction projects or water usage not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 exempt certain construction activities from environmental laws, with final settlement of tribal water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. The Tribes retain rights on other streams, can participate in the project, receive dedicated water, and acquire water rights under Colorado law. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allow tribal participation in the Animas-La Plata Project and acquisition of water rights under Colorado law. The Attorney General of the United States is required to amend the final consent decree with Water Division Number 7 in the State of Colorado. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of the Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as outlined in various Appropriations Acts. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as referenced in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, remains available for funding components of the Animas-La Plata Project not covered in the original agreement.
